page.title: 02ECOLOGY - LANDSCAPE
page.content: The study area is a plateau at around 700' above sea level near the crest of the Cotswolds. It slopes gently from west to east and is etched by the valleys of several small streams, of which the most important drains a network of valleys to the N.E. towards the River Frome at Stroud. The plateau surface is formed of Tresham Rock, part of the Great Oolite. It is dry open scenery interupted only by dry stone walls and occasional copses. The deeper valleys reach down into the Cotteswold Sand. Much of the valley side land below 600' is affected by landslips caused by periglacial conditions during the ice age. The valley sides provide variety with larger fingers of woodland and the scenery justifies its inclusion in the Cotswold "Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty".
